Chat Support:

 Thanks for your answers! Based on what you’ve shared, it sounds like the issue is likely related to HTTPS filtering (also known as SSL inspection). Modern browsers like Edge and Chrome use HTTPS for most sites, and without HTTPS filtering enabled on Exinda, the appliance can’t see or block the encrypted traffic—while Firefox may behave differently due to its own certificate handling.

Let’s check if HTTPS filtering is enabled and, if not, I can guide you through setting it up. Here’s what I need to know:
- Are you familiar with configuring policies or filters on your Exinda appliance?
- Do you have access to the Exinda web interface (admin dashboard)?
- Would you like step-by-step instructions on how to enable HTTPS filtering/SSL inspection?

Once I know your comfort level and access, I’ll walk you through the next steps! 
Weissa:

 1- yes 2- yes 3- yes 
Chat Support:

 Great, since you’re comfortable with the Exinda web interface and want to enable HTTPS filtering (SSL inspection), here’s how you can block HTTPS sites in browsers like Edge and Chrome:

STEP-BY-STEP: BLOCKING HTTPS SITES ON EXINDA

1. Identify the HTTPS Site’s Certificate Common Name
- Go to Monitor > Real Time in the Exinda WebUI.
- Filter by the IP address involved and look for flows at the start of the conversation.
- You should see an entry like HTTPS [URL]—the URL in brackets is the certificate’s common name.

2. Create an Application Object
- Navigate to Configuration > Objects > Applications.
- Create a new application object:
- Set the L7 signature to SSL.
- For the common name, use the root domain or a key part of the URL you found earlier.
- Example: If the common name is facebook.com, just use that.

3. Create a Discard Policy
- Go to the Optimizer.
- Create a new policy using the application object you just made.
- Set the action to Discard.
- Apply this policy to the relevant virtual circuit.

4. Restart the Optimizer
- After making these changes, restart the Optimizer to apply the new policy.

For more detailed instructions, you can check out this article: Discarding HTTPS Specific Traffic [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120513].

If you want to block adult content or other categories, you can follow a similar process, as described here: Blocking Adult Content Sites on a Virtual Circuit [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/119349].

Let me know if you’d like a more detailed walkthrough for any of these steps, or if you run into any issues! 
Weissa:

 i checked and i am using L7 defined application in exinda itself 
Chat Support:

 Thanks for checking! If you’re already using an L7-defined application in Exinda, but HTTPS sites are still not being blocked in Edge and Chrome, there are a couple of important things to consider:

WHY L7 SIGNATURES ALONE MAY NOT BLOCK HTTPS IN MODERN BROWSERS

- L7 (Layer 7) signatures can identify and block unencrypted (HTTP) traffic or some basic HTTPS patterns, but they often can’t see inside encrypted HTTPS traffic unless SSL inspection (HTTPS filtering) is specifically configured.
- Modern browsers encrypt almost all traffic, so Exinda can only see that it’s HTTPS traffic—not the specific site—unless you use the “common name” method described earlier.

WHAT YOU CAN DO NEXT

1. Double-Check Application Object Settings
- Is your L7 application object using “SSL” as the signature and specifying the common name (domain) of the site you want to block?
- If it’s just set to “HTTPS” or a generic signature, it may not match specific sites.

2. Try the Common Name Method
- As described in the article Discarding HTTPS Specific Traffic [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120513], create an application object with:
- L7 Signature: SSL
- Common Name: (e.g., facebook.com)
- Then, apply a discard policy for this object.

3. Test with a New Policy
- After creating the new application object and discard policy, restart the Optimizer.
- Test in Edge and Chrome to see if the block page or error appears.

QUICK CHECKLIST

- Are you using “SSL” as the L7 signature, not just “HTTPS”?
- Did you specify the domain (common name) in the application object?
- Did you restart the Optimizer after making changes?

If you’ve done all of the above and it’s still not working, let me know exactly how your application object is configured (what signature and values you’re using), and I can help you fine-tune it!

Would you like to share a screenshot or the details of your current application object setup? Or, if you want, I can walk you through creating a new one step-by-step.
